title: Studies in Comparative Anti-Racism (SCAR)
text:
What strategies effectively dismantle structural racism and quell racially motivated violence? Research on structural racism proposes multiple paths towards decreasing race disparities. However, the effectiveness of these recommendations is largely empirically unsubstantiated because of the dismal track record of dismantling racism in the United States.
To address these questions, we employ a computational approach combined with in depth case analysis to construct the first longitudinal database on racism and strategies to combat racism world-wide. With attention to the theoretical tenets for addressing racism and under standing minority agency and innovation in face of racial inequity, this extensive collection of empirical evidence situates African Americans, Asian American-Pacific Islanders (AAPI), and Latinx Americans in a larger cross-national group-level database, supplemented with sub-national case study data from across the world.

The Maryland team
The SCAR team at the University of Maryland consists of faculty from the Behavioral and Social Sciences, Government and Politics (Birnir, Calvo and Johnson), and from Decisions Operations and Information Technology and Management and Organisation in the Smith Business School (respectively Bjarnad√≥ttir and Waguespack). (Several members of the team in were founding members of the Interdisciplinary Laboratory of Computational Social Siences (ilcss.umd.edu)) The Phd students on the Maryland team are Overos, Pathak and Dewar.


The inter-University team
The Maryland team is nested in a larger inter-University collaboration with researchers from the University of Michigan (led by Davenport), the newly created Politics of Race and Ethnicity Lab at the University of Texas at Austin (directed by Liu and McDaniel), and researchers at Howard University (led by Lusane).

Cross national indicators coming soon
SCAR aims to build a unique large scale database using new computational methods and supplement at-scale data collection with important national level case studies.
The foundational AMAR data (All Minorities at Risk) is the most extensive cross-national longitudinal data collection in the world about minorities, their actions and treatment by the state. The data contains variables that will allow us to begin to explore varying discrimination and its correlates cross-nationally (Birnir et.al. 2018).
We will apply the method to sort through large amount of information to code for political actions and treatment of over 1,200 AMAR groups. The development will also address theoretical issues that come with a fluid group-level variable like ethnicity. Once refined at the aggregate level this method can be applied at the sub-national level to gather nuanced local level data in local languages.
